word.description: {蘋} is from a Sanskrit translation and {果} is {果} is [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit).

images.place: Chinatown Supermarket, South Salt Lake, Utah

word.description: {火龍} is *fire dragon* ({火} is *fire* and {龍} is *dragon*), and {果} is {果} is [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit), so {火龍果} is *fire dragon fruit*.

description:
**Warning**

[Durian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durian) has a strong flavor and odor, so it's a notoriously acquired taste.

word.description: {奇異} sounds like *kiwi* but also means *strange*, and {果} is {果} is [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit), so {奇異果} is *strange fruit*.

images.place: Chinatown Supermarket, South Salt Lake, Utah

description: [Kiwi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiwifruit) are native to China also known as *Chinese gooseberry*.

word.description: As in English, {橙} denotes both the [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(fruit)) and the [color](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(colour)).

images.place: Wendy's Noodle Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: [Oranges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(fruit)) originated in China and neighboring regions. [Mandarin oranges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandarin_orange) in particular are a traditional gift/offering during Chinese New Year, because the Cantonese word for Mandarin orange, 柑 (gām) sounds like the word for gold, 金 (gām).

word.description: {芒} is phonetic for the first syllable in [mango](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mango), and {果} is {果} is [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit) but also sounds like the second syllable in [mango](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mango).

images.place: Hui Lau Shan, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: Mango is a tropical fruit, likely originating from south Asia, and present in many Hong Kong desserts such as the dim sum favorite [mango pudding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mango_pudding), mango pancakes, and fruit teas.

word.description: {菠蘿} is a phonetic word for [pineapple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pineapple) (although it's not very close). In Taiwan, {鳳梨} is more commonly used.

images.place: Chinatown Supermarket, South Salt Lake, Utah

description: [Pineapples](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pineapple) originated in South America and are cultivated in tropical climes around the world, including [Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pineapple_production_in_Taiwan), famous for their [pineapple cakes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pineapple_cake) (featured in their airport gift shops).
Peanuts are grown mostly in tropical and subtropical regions, with production led by China.

word.description: {冬} is *winter*, and {瓜} is *melon* (or *gourd* or *squash*), so {冬瓜} is *winter melon*.

images.place: Chinatown Supermarket, South Salt Lake, Utah

description: Winter melon, also known as wax gourd due to its waxy coating (which contributes to a long shelf life), is present in a variety of Chinese foods, from winter melon soup, candies, stir-frieds, and winter melon teas.

word.description: {百} is *hundred*, {香} is *fragrant*, and {果}is [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit), so {百香果} is *hundred fragrant fruit*.

images.place: Chinatown Supermarket, South Salt Lake, Utah

word.description: {話} is *colloquial* and {梅} is *plum*, so {話梅} is *colloquial plum*.

images.place: Chung Chou City, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: Salted dried plums are a popular snack in China, Korea, and Japan, and brought by Chinese immigrants to the Polynesia and Philippines (where it is known as [ciamoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiamoy)), and by Filipino immigrants to Mexico (where it is known as [saladitos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saladitos).
